questions.question: Which numeric attribute that varies the most can be explained by a few other measurements? Return as JSON with keys: target, predictors, r_squared, adj_r_squared, n_significant, coefficients, p_values.
questions.hint: Pick the numeric column with the highest variance, identify its three most correlated numeric features, fit a linear regression, and report the model statistics.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "predictors" (list of 3 column names), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "adj_r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "n_significant" (integer count of predictors with p < 0.05), "coefficients" (dict mapping predictor names to coefficients rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_values" (dict mapping predictor names to p-values rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "predictors": ["sqft", "bedrooms", "age"], "r_squared": 0.7234, "adj_r_squared": 0.7156, "n_significant": 2, "coefficients": {"sqft": 123.45, "bedrooms": 5000.12, "age": -200.34}, "p_values": {"sqft": 0.000001, "bedrooms": 0.023456, "age": 0.156789}}

questions.question: Which numeric measurement in the diamonds dataset is most skewed, and what are its mean and bootstrap confidence interval? Return as JSON with keys: column, skewness, mean, ci_lower, ci_upper, std_error, n_bootstrap.
questions.hint: Calculate absolute skewness for each numeric column, select the highest, then use bootstrap resampling to estimate the mean, its 95% CI, and standard error.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column" (name of most skewed column), "skewness" (rounded to 4 decimals), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "ci_lower" (lower bound of 95% CI, rounded to 4 decimals), "ci_upper" (upper bound, rounded to 4 decimals), "std_error" (bootstrap standard error, rounded to 4 decimals), and "n_bootstrap" (integer, the number of bootstrap samples). Example: {"column": "income", "skewness": 2.3456, "mean": 50000.1234, "ci_lower": 48500.5678, "ci_upper": 51500.9012, "std_error": 750.3456, "n_bootstrap": 1000}

questions.question: Which numeric attribute best predicts the most variable column in the diamonds data? Return as JSON with keys: target, best_predictor, correlation, r_squared, coefficient, p_value.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the highest variance, compute absolute correlations with the others, pick the strongest, fit a simple OLS regression and report the stats.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "best_predictor" (column name), "correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "coefficient" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "best_predictor": "sqft", "correlation": 0.834, "r_squared": 0.6956, "coefficient": 135.2847, "p_value": 0.000001}

questions.question: Which numeric attribute in the diamonds data is closest to a normal distribution? Return as JSON with keys: column, ks_statistic, p_value, is_normal, sample_mean, sample_std.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the lowest absolute skewness, compute its mean and std, standardize it, then perform a Kolmogorov‑Smirnov test against a standard normal.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (tested column), "ks_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "is_normal" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05), "sample_mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "sample_std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "height", "ks_statistic": 0.0456, "p_value": 0.234567, "is_normal": true, "sample_mean": 170.1234, "sample_std": 10.5678}

questions.question: Does the most variable numeric attribute show different variances across diamond cut categories? Return as JSON with keys: target_column, grouping_column, n_groups, levene_statistic, p_value, variances_equal, group_variances.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the highest variance, select a categorical column with a moderate number of levels, then apply Levene's test to compare group variances.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "target_column", "grouping_column", "n_groups" (integer), "levene_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "variances_equal" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05), and "group_variances" (dict mapping group names to variance rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"target_column": "score", "grouping_column": "class", "n_groups": 3, "levene_statistic": 2.3456, "p_value": 0.098765, "variances_equal": true, "group_variances": {"A": 123.4567, "B": 145.6789, "C": 112.3456}}

questions.question: Which two numeric measurements in the diamond dataset are most strongly monotonic correlated? Return as JSON with keys: columns, spearman_rho, p_value, interpretation.
questions.hint: Calculate the Spearman correlation matrix for all numeric columns, identify the pair with the highest absolute correlation, and report its rho, p‑value, and interpretation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "spearman_rho" (correlation coefficient rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), and "interpretation" (string: "strong", "moderate", "weak", or "negligible"). Example: {"columns": ["age", "income"], "spearman_rho": 0.7234, "p_value": 0.000001, "interpretation": "strong"}

questions.question: Which pair of numeric variables in the diamonds dataset are the most skewed and how does a log transformation affect their correlation? Return as JSON with keys: columns, original_correlation, log_correlation, improvement, transformation_helpful.
questions.hint: Identify the two numeric columns with the highest absolute skewness, compute their Pearson correlation, apply a log1p transform to both, recompute the correlation, and compare the absolute values.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 5 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "original_correlation" (Pearson, rounded to 4 decimals), "log_correlation" (after log transform, rounded to 4 decimals), "improvement" (absolute difference, rounded to 4 decimals), and "transformation_helpful" (boolean, true if |log_corr| > |orig_corr|). Example: {"columns": ["income", "spending"], "original_correlation": 0.4567, "log_correlation": 0.7234, "improvement": 0.2667, "transformation_helpful": true}

questions.question: Which numeric column shows the greatest spread, and what are its quartile-based outlier thresholds? Return as JSON with keys: column, q1, q3, iqr, lower_fence, upper_fence, n_outliers.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric feature with the highest variance, then compute its Q1, Q3, IQR, lower and upper fences, and count how many values fall outside these fences.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "q1" (25th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "q3" (75th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "iqr" (rounded to 4 decimals), "lower_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), "upper_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "n_outliers" (integer count). Example: {"column": "salary", "q1": 45000.0000, "q3": 75000.0000, "iqr": 30000.0000, "lower_fence": 0.0000, "upper_fence": 120000.0000, "n_outliers": 23}

questions.question: Which category of a diamond attribute has the highest average index number when considering the most variable numeric measurement? Return as JSON with keys: category_column, best_category, target_column, mean_value.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the greatest variance, then calculate its mean for each categorical column and pick the category with the highest mean.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "category_column" (the grouping column name), "best_category" (the category value with highest mean), "target_column" (the numeric column analyzed), and "mean_value" (rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"category_column": "region", "best_category": "West", "target_column": "sales", "mean_value": 1234.567}

questions.question: Which pair of numeric measurements in the diamond dataset are most strongly correlated, and how does that relationship change after removing extreme outliers? Return as JSON with keys: columns, original_correlation, outliers_removed, clean_correlation.
questions.hint: Compute absolute correlations to find the strongest pair, filter out rows beyond 3 standard deviations for both columns, then recompute the correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "original_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "outliers_removed" (integer count), and "clean_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "original_correlation": 0.847, "outliers_removed": 12, "clean_correlation": 0.891}

questions.question: How many numeric attributes contain outliers and what is the total number of outlier values in the dataset? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: Use a 3‑standard‑deviation rule on each numeric column to flag outliers, then count columns with any outliers and sum all outlier occurrences.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: How many numeric attributes have extreme values, and what is the total count of those outliers in the dataset? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: For each numeric column, flag values beyond 2.5 standard deviations from the mean, then count columns with any flags and sum all flagged values.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: Which pair of numeric attributes in the diamonds dataset are most strongly correlated? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Compute the absolute correlation matrix for all numeric columns and identify the off‑diagonal pair with the highest value.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the correlation coefficient rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.847}

questions.question: Which two numeric attributes in the diamonds data have the weakest correlation? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Compute the absolute correlation matrix for numeric columns, mask the diagonal, locate the smallest non‑zero correlation, sort the column names alphabetically, and round the correlation to three decimals.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the absolute correlation value rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.012}

questions.question: Which numeric column has the greatest variance across the diamonds and what is its mean? Return as JSON with keys: x, y, z.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the highest variance, then compute its mean.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the mean), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: Which numeric attribute in the diamonds data has the smallest average value, and what is its standard deviation? Return as JSON with keys: result.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the lowest mean, then compute its standard deviation.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the standard deviation), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: Are there any columns in the dataset that have a substantial amount of missing data? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the missing percentage for each column and identify those above a 5% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Are there any columns in the diamonds dataset that have a high percentage of missing values? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the missing‑value percentage per column, flag those above a 10% threshold, and list their names.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Which numeric column spans the widest range, and what are its key percentiles? Return as JSON with keys: column, p10, p25, p50, p75, p90.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the largest max‑min range, then compute its 10th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 90th percentiles.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "p10" (10th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "p25" (25th percentile), "p50" (median), "p75" (75th percentile), and "p90" (90th percentile). Example: {"column": "income", "p10": 25000.0000, "p25": 40000.0000, "p50": 55000.0000, "p75": 75000.0000, "p90": 100000.0000}

questions.question: Which numeric feature in the diamonds data shows the greatest variability across all records? Return as JSON with keys: column, count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, kurtosis.
questions.hint: Calculate variance for each numeric column, select the one with the highest variance, then compute its descriptive statistics.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 9 keys: "column", "count" (integer), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "std", "min", "max", "median", "skewness", and "kurtosis" (all rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "age", "count": 1000, "mean": 35.4567, "std": 12.3456, "min": 18.0000, "max": 85.0000, "median": 34.0000, "skewness": 0.5678, "kurtosis": -0.2345}
